Arguably one of the greatest UK comedians of all time.Â   There's not a lot of comedians that have the ability to command and dictate a room full of other comedians like Sean could. Personally not a lot of comedians could make me cry with laughter like he could.  I've never really been truly bothered or upset when a celebrity passes, whether I was a big fan or not, but hearing that Sean had passed really affected me. Compared to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) in 2003, the novel coronavirus that broke out in China last year has spread faster and wider, affecting more than 50 countries in just two months. There have also been cases in which the incubation period extends beyond 14 days and the infected patients show no symptoms, making it harder to stem the virus' spread.  Another challenge is the lack of preventive vaccines or therapeutic drugs. Although a number of companies are working or planning to work on it, the outcome remains uncertain. Remdesivir, a new drug made by Gilead Sciences, for example, is expected to work only on mild or moderate cases. The lengthy drug approval process may also mean that even before a drug is put on the market, the quick spread and mutation of the virus may have made it beyond treatment.  Some hope that the epidemic would fade like SARS as the temperature rises, but there is no evidence yet. â€œWe absolutely donâ€™t know that,â€ says Trudie Lang at the University of Oxford. â€œI keep asking virologist colleagues this and nobody knows.â€  Millions of people are placed under quarantine as the Chinese communist regime scrambles to contain the virus. With no end of quarantine in sight, many, especially those in Wuhan, feel trapped in their own homes, and their mental health is worrisome, which may lead to another humanitarian crisis.  As China's leaders grapple with the epidemic and its devastating impact on the economy and people's physical and psychological well-being, I am writing this open letter to share my understanding of the plague. I hope that they will learn from history and find a solution that addresses the fundamental, underlying causes of the epidemic.  Plagues in Ancient Times A lot can be learned from plagues in the ancient times, whether in China or in the West. During the Ming Dynasty, for example, a plague broke out in 1580 and infected more than half of the families in Datong (in todayâ€™s Shanxi Province), and it later spread to Beijing as well as southern China. When it broke out again in Shanxi Province in 1633, many people fled and some families had no survivors. Another surge of the plague in 1641, three years before the dynastyâ€™s end, wiped out a significant portion of the population in China.  Besides plagues, the Ming Dynasty also faced other threats, such as the rebelling forces from Li Zicheng (also known as the Dashing King). The plagues, though, seemed to infect only the Ming Dynastyâ€™s troops, not soldiers of Li Zicheng or the invading Manchus. Moreover, after infecting China for decades and weakening the Ming forces, the plague diminished in 1644 after the Manchu established the Qing Dynasty. To some extent, this plague seemed to be a catalyst for the transition of dynasties.  In the West, the plagues in the Roman Empire were also well known in history. After Nero began to persecute Christians, several major plagues took place: the Autumn Plague in 65 AD, the Antonine Plague (165-180), the Plague of Cyprian (250-270), and the Plague of Justinian (541-542).  During the Antonine Plague, for example, there were up to 2,000 deaths a day in Rome. With a mortality rate of about 25%, the total deaths were estimated at five million. The disease killed as much as one-third of the population in some areas and weakened the Roman army, ending a relatively peaceful period of Roman history.  The plagues stopped miraculously after people awakened in 680 and began to reflect on the cruelty against Christians as well as the general moral decay of society. In 680, Roman citizens carried the bones of Saint Sebastian (256-288, killed during the persecution by Diocletian) and processed through the streets. As people repented of their wrongdoings, the plague miraculously vanished in Rome.  People in other areas of the empire heard about this and followed their example, asking for the bones of Saint Sebastian to offer repentance. When a plague broke out in Venice in 1575, about 50,000 people died. Similarly, a plague occurred in Lisbon in 1599. In both cases, people marched with the bones of holy people in repentance, and the plagues ended.  Origin of the Coronavirus Outbreak So how did the coronavirus epidemic start in Wuhan? One theory pointed to a seafood market in Wuhan, but the first documented COVID-19 cases had never been to the seafood market. Attention was soon turned to Chinaâ€™s only Biosafety Level 4 microbiology lab in the Wuhan Institute of Virology, known as the National Biosafety Laboratory and equipped to handle deadly coronaviruses, Ebola, and other pathogens.  The New York Post published an article on February 22, 2020, warning its readers, â€œDonâ€™t buy Chinaâ€™s story: The coronavirus may have leaked from a lab.â€ The article noted, â€œthe Peopleâ€™s Liberation Armyâ€™s top expert in biological warfare, a Maj. Gen. Chen Wei, was dispatched to Wuhan at the end of January to help with the effort to contain the outbreak.â€ Chen is an expert who has studied SARS, Ebola, and anthrax. The report pointed out, â€œThis would not be her [Chen's] first trip to the Wuhan Institute of Virology either, since it is one of only two bioweapons research labs in all of China.â€  Whatever the theories are, the outcome of the epidemic is disastrous to China. So many people are dying, and the economy is suffering badly.  While people are venting their distrust in the government and calling for a change of the system, I believe there is a deeper reason for everything.  History Has the Answer Much like the plagues in ancient Rome that occurred after Nero began to persecute Christians, I believe that the fundamental reason for the coronavirus outbreak is the Chinese communist regime's persecution of Falun Gong practitioners.  Falun Gong, a meditation system based on the principles of Truthfulness-Compassion-Forbearance, has enabled millions of its practitioners to improve both health and character since its introduction to the public in 1992. Its main teachings, Zhuan Falun, has been translated into 40 languages, and people in more than 100 countries practice the spiritual discipline.  As more and more people were drawn to Falun Gong, Jiang Zemin launched a nationwide campaign against the practice in July 1999. The scale and severity of the persecution are unprecedented.  In the past 20 years, numerous practitioners have been arrested, detained, imprisoned, tortured, or even had their organs harvested. More than 4,300 are confirmed to have died as a result of the persecution. Due to the communist regime's information blockade, the actual death toll is likely to be much higher.  Jiangâ€™s policy of â€œdefaming their [Falun gong practitionersâ€™] reputation, bankrupting them financially, and destroying them physicallyâ€ is no less severe than what Nero did to Christians.  One plague after another struck Rome after the persecution of Christians began. If history is any indication, could the current coronavirus outbreak be a hint from heaven to warn against the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners, which has entered its 21st year in 2020?

Sean has always been one of my favorites because he seems so effortlessly funny and genuinely fun to be around. my favorite moments were with him & Miles, they just couldn't stop giggling together. it must have been such an honor to be able to make him laugh. never did I dream I'd be so affected by the death of someone who randomly showed up in my recommended clips a few years ago, but my heart aches from his loss. it's so hard to believe it's real, and I can't imagine what those close to him must be going through. I'm so glad to have all these clips of him to remember him by, but my heart breaks knowing countdown could never be the same without him. I took my (now) wife skiing in Mayrhofen, Austria about 7 or so years back. We had no idea that there was an English comedy festival in town, and Sean Lock was appearing. We went out for a romantic dinner to a quiet little restaurant on the outskirts of town one night, and who was there, but Sean Lock and a load of his comedian mates. We sat on a table opposite them, and they just ripped the proverbial out of us all night. He joked that he'd spoiled my chance to propose, and I replied, it's OK, the ring only cost me Â£9.99 from Argos, I can take it back.  He ended up buying us a bottle of wine and we had a great fun evening. RIP Sean - you were one of the best. Our sympathies to your family and friends.

If Sean had been a politician, we would have been hearing from some dour commentator about the influence he had brought to achieve the odd bit of good in his electorate. If he'd been a sportsman, we would have seen a few highlights of his best moments on the track/field. Would that have made us feel better? I suspect not. Instead, we've had the pleasure of watching, and laughing, and crying, as these clips have evidenced his supreme skill as a comedian. And we felt better afterwards. I'm sure his comedic skills have improved the lives of many more people than most politicians, because laughter is truly a tonic which should be taken at least once a day.

Always liked Sean's dry humour and quips and read in Wikipedia that Andre Tarkovsky's 1979 sci-fi film Stalker greatly affected him. Never saw the film but was certainly affected when I played 3 of the Stalker PC games released where you play a stalker, a kind of nomadic wanderer in a radioactive wilderness. In Chernobyl, Fall of Pripyat, the digital artists have lovingly created a scale model of Pripyat with the iconic Ferris wheel and funfair in which you can wonder around if you choose to, the towns inhabitants had once serviced the nearby Chernobyl nuke plant. You can see why it would have affected Sean because it got me too. A few years ago watching a documentary on Pripyat the Ghost town, and I was right back into the game.  15 Storeys High, his series about the tenants of a high-rise is a classic, one of my favourite episodes was about Blue, a Polish energy drink that turned your tongue that colour.  Ed Power of the Daily Telegraph once wrote 'Sean was a Samuel Beckett trapped in a Tommy Cooper punchline.'
Absolute comedy legend. RIP Sean, we'll miss ya.

I started watching 8 out of 10 cats does Countdown clips a few months back. Binged through compilations the whole night, laughed so hard I cried sometimes.  Being from Singapore, we don't get stuff like this on our TV, obviously, so I had no idea this existed. I only found this because I searched up Jimmy Carr, having seen him on Celebrity Juice years back (another YouTube find).  I instantly fell in love with Sean Lock's character. My favourite moment of his was when Rachel Riley was donning the Viking helmet and a beard and he retorted "that's a challenging wank". I eagerly waited for new compilations.  Just two days ago, I got the news that he passed on. It really hit me like a truck even though I never knew him, because he was just such a valuable asset to British comedy and to the show.  His jokes got me through some tough times via the show, and I am eternally grateful for that. Its unfortunate the rest of us won't get to witness this man in action any more, but I'm sure he's cracking up the masses in Heaven.  Rest in peace, Sean. You will be sorely missed.

I have never mourned the death of a celebrity - I've been sad, but I can't mourn for someone I've never met and didn't truly know.  Sean is different.  For those familiar with his comedy, he made the world a better, brighter place, even on his darkest journeys into the absurd.  He had a quality about him that made it seem like if you bumped into him in the street he'd gladly stop and chat.  On three separate occasions, Sean almost caused me to die in the manner second on my list of the ways I'd want to die: laughing so hard a blood vessel in my brain pops.  News of his death brought me the same pain I felt in January this year when my aunt passed, though that pain is mitigated by videos like this.  While they exist, and people still laugh, he will never truly be gone.
Sean was a gift. Rest in peace.

My dad bought me a Sean Lock DVD when I was about 14, his humour was right up my dads street. He reminds me of my dad in a lot of ways, very clever, very dry, witty sense of humour, sort of seems to hate the world but at the same time is probably one of the nicest people you'll ever meet. We watched that DVD together all those years ago, and I remember we were both absolutely creased up laughing. I've been a big fan of his ever since. My partner and I often stick on some countdown clips if we wanna cheer up after a hard day, these clips are all brilliant but not even his best ones. He was just consistently so funny, so clever, such an excellent comic...really knew his craft. Had a little cry yesterday when I found out he had passed, had another little cry just now watching this. I've only ever cried at a celebrity dying once before in my life and that was when David Bowie died. I really held Sean in high esteem, and I am truly saddened that he's gone, and that the world will never hear more of his jokes. I hope he is at peace, and I wish his family all the best.

Proof that there is no God, all the cnuts in the world and he took this man. You will be missed.
Gut punch, for me, yesterday. Refreshed my Twitter feed, yesterday morninf and it came up, as breaking news. Took the fuckin wind out of me. I remember seeing him, when a new series of 8 Out of Ten Cats Does Countdown broadcast and he had a shaven head and a sort of beard. Shocked me a bit. Then, on a few episodes after, he had a hoarse voice. Read on Twitter, a director that worked on his last stand up tour that he was possibly afflicted in 2017. Kept it largely private. I admire that. No fuss. He didn't want it. Fuckin brilliant comedian. Nobody like him. The world is awash now with stand ups, panel shows, sitcoms. There's dedicated channels just for 'comedy'. Can't speak for other countries, but, in the UK, he was worth his weight in gold for what he brought to shows he was involved in. They style, the delivery, the creativity, that shock he sometimes brought. I liked him before, but, I remember seeing him on the Jonathan Ross Show, when it was massive and on BBC1. He told a tale about how he got skin cancer when he was 22-23. And he said something along the lines of "I used to work on building sites. So, you'd have your shirt off a lot of the time. And it's really difficult to ask an Irish foreman if he'd rub some Ambre Solaire on. 'Mick?! You wouldn't be a poppett, would you?'" He had an Irish parent, and I think he was that fine line between respectable working class and lower middle class. That tale, I'll always remember, as I'm from Irish parentage that were and some might say (due to my behavior), respectable working class/middle class. Loved him. I'm one of them people (36) that never really went along with the culture of my time. Grew up in the 90's in inner city London, when kids were either into the UK boybands or garage/happy house. Shite, to me. I was tryna get hold of vinyls to listen to the greats of rock n roll, soul, blues, country. All the comedy I was watching and still do, is stuff before I was born. I was of the the thinking, and still am to a point - "Nobody know can touch what's come before." He did. One of Britain's best. Nobody like him. Fuckin loved him. Always will.
RIP, he was a true legend and a national treasure.

Rest In Peace Eternal Sean .  Near a shady wall a rose once grew, Budded and blossomed in God's free light, Watered and fed by the morning dew, Shedding it's sweetness day and night.  As it grew and blossomed fair and tall, Slowly rising to loftier height, It came to a crevice in the wall Through which there shone a beam of light.  Onward it crept with added strength With never a thought of fear or pride, It followed the light through the crevice's length And unfolded itself on the other side.  The light, the dew, the broadening view Were found the same as they were before, And it lost itself in beauties new, Breathing it's fragrance more and more.  Shall claim of death cause us to grieve And make our courage faint and fall? Nay! Let us faith and hope receive-- The rose still grows beyond the wall,  Scattering fragrance far and wide Just as it did in days of yore, Just as it did on the other side, Just as it will forever-more. This video made me cry  I remember a "bit" that he did on something, some stand-up I think, talking about how he'd had skin cancer when working as a roofer or labourer, I'm sorry I don't remember the job exactly.  From what I recall he made light of it, told it with humour, it was a part of his show and delivered with typical Sean Lock style.  But I remember him saying about the situation, a "masculine environment"/macho culture in the workplace, and always working shirtless outdoors in the sun, and not wanting to ask the boss to rub some sun lotion on their backs etc, and you can't reach yourself so you don't bother, and as such how men are more likely to develop skin cancers on their backs.   I don't know what took him - too young.   I don't know if it was related to the above, but he brought that awareness to me that I didn't have before. And probably, hopefully to other people too, who might then have otherwise been affected by skin cancer.   But instead decided to always wear sunscreen

I hardly ever watched "8 out of 10" in real time. I couldn't have told you Sean's name if you asked me to. At the start of this week I clicked on a link for "8 out of 10" and laughed. I kept clicking and I laughed more and more. I wondered to myself how I missed a decade of this. I found myself laughing most when Sean started on some surreal nonsensical trip with no obvious ending. I'd end myself. The cast would end themselves. The audience would end themselves. Sean would sit there (mostly perfectly) composed and wondering what the fuss was about.  This morning while absently doing the dishes and listening to the radio I heard he'd died. I knew instantly that I thought I knew this guy. And then his face appeared. The big square jaw, peg teeth, square glasses, widow's peak, crinkly eyes. His beautiful sense of absurdity. So sad. I found you much too late Sean. But I found you. Go well.

A lot of people have died in my older years. Davie Bowie, George Michael, Prince Philip, Michael Jackson, Prince and so many more. And today, when it was announced on the radio in my car, that Sean Lock had died, was the first time that I let out a gasp of "No!". I was shocked. And today, I am very sad. Of course, I don't know him from Adam, but my god, he has entertained me over the years and literally makes tears run down my eyes. I laugh every time I watch him, even if I've seen the gags before. And that, that very quality in a funny man, is what I believe marks out the genius from just very funny. There aren't (or should I say weren't?) many like him and now we have one less. If there is an afterlife, where ever Sean has gone is better off and I really hope I end up there. RIP. You are a treasure that we are lucky to have recorded. May you forever win, "Carrot in a Box".

When I was at uni aged 19 just a few years ago, I was so close to ending my life. I was thinking of ways to do this, I had one of Seanâ€™s best bits videos in the background on YouTube. It gave me a sense of comfort. Suddenly I paused my brain from thinking and turned my attention to the video â€œWhat would you want your orbituary to say sean?â€   â€œI donâ€™t care, Iâ€™d be deadâ€ in the severe depressive state I was this made me laugh so much because he was joking about the very thing which I could have faced, death. And laughing at my own situation was a coping mechanism for me. But that line from Sean made me realise that if I was still able to laugh even at my lowest point, then life was worth carrying on for. Sean will never know but he saved my life that day and whenever I feel shit I will always watch his clips. A few years ago I met him. A man next to me dropped his change when I was on my break from work so I helped him pick it up. The man said "oh that the last thing I needed" with a kind of sarcastic huff because of dropping his change. I instantly recognised the voice and looked up to see Sean Lock smiling at me as I handed him the coins. I felt so silly after I blurted out that he was mine and my Dad's favourite on 8 of 10 cats does countdown especially when I had to continue standing next to him whilst we both waited for our drinks to be handed to us. But when I finally got my order (relief because I thought I'd come across a complete weirdo) and I walked back to work, he gave me a big friendly smile. I'm now so glad I said it to him, and even though our interaction wasn't much of an interaction he was so nice to me. I'll always remember that.

One of the absolute funniest ever
I don't typically care about celebrity deaths, as they don't impact my life much, and I feel no personal connection to them, but when I heard about Sean this morning, I was genuinely saddened. I've been obsessed with panel shows since I found them many years back. We don't have anything quite the same in the US. Sean has been a staple of the majority of my favorite panel shows since the beginning, and has always given off a hilarious uncle vibe, and it feels almost like I've lost my favorite uncle today. The world is at a loss. With everything we have to bring us down every day, we now have one less thing to bring us back to center, and that's something I feel that's desperately needed in this world. Even in the past weeks people have sent me clips of him doing "carrot in a box" and his "difficult wank" comment from 8 out of 10 cats. I'm sure his loved ones are gutted right now, but I hope they find solace in knowing how much joy he brought the world during his lifetime. RIP Sean Lock.

I just can't imagine anyone filling his seat as Captain... He was so genuine and a purely natural humour, endlessly so.  I know they have a confrontational dynamic on the show, but fuck... I dread to think how Jon Richardson is going to feel during the next few recordings of whatever panel show he ends up filming after this. I don't think it would matter which show, just looking over at another Desk in any Studio would make me damned depressed.  I really can't think of anyone who is as natural and relatable as Sean Lock...  Based on his earthy wisdom and everyman style, I suppose I would want Mickey Flannigan. Based on his whimsy and commitment to absurdity, I guess only Eddie Izzard would do. Based on his exaggeration of misery, obviously Jack Dee is his closest Brother. Based on his dry and parodic treatment of dark or twisted or disgusting topics, I think Miles Jupp was a stalwart ally in a world of politically sensitive people.  The truth however, is that none of these people could ever supply me with everything that Sean Lock did, on this show, in his stand-up (Lockepedia makes me laugh out loud, uproariously, at least once per viewing, and I have viewed it around 80 times), or as a Guest on Big Fat Quiz... That year he and James Cordon were teamed together, I honestly almost pissed myself, genuine straining was needed to keep my bladder closed.  I honestly love you, Sean Lock. You did us all proud.
